Comment content:
*some of these are medicine specific
Prompt 1 : USMLE examiner examining medical OSCE stations. Ask [Nbr] questions for the OSCE station : [fill in]. Waiting for my response before asking each question. First then wait then ask the second. At the end go back and critique my response to each question w/ providing example answers.
Prompt 2 : Topic of your choice. You are a learning and productivity expert. Create a focused learning plan on the topic using the Pareto Principle. Focus on the most valuable high-yield elements of the topic. Active methods of learning over passive. No pretext or context just output the plan. 
Prompt 3 : You are an expert in so and so. Providing a step by step guide for performing the said maneuver.
Prompt 4 : Learning expert specializing in above mentioned topic, provide mental models and analogies to help understand and remember. List of steps (explain, provide mental models ad analogies, quick example exercices or questions to practice w/ you, break down the topic into smaller components. Ask me if I understand after each step
Prompt 5 : Language role play
Prompt 6 : Clinical case or any simulated case
Prompt 7 : Expert in said topic, provide me evidence-based learning techniques
Prompt 8 : Visualization exercise to be guided through
Video title: How to Use GPT-4 to Easily Learn Any Skill

Comment content:
Ai detector is a meme, tired yesterday with chatgpt output, gave me 100% human.

Just making the prompts slightly more complex than "write an article about x" will make it undetectable, or just passing chatGpt output into another paraphrasing algorithm will also make it undetectable.
Also.slightly editing ChatGpt output (1min of work if you are slow) will also give a false negative of 100% human.

Also these ai "detectors" only work on English output, trying other languages will always give false negatives.

Unless openAI relases GPT-3 / CHATGPT weights (non going to happen ever) there is no realistic way to detect if text is written by an ai or by an human.

Comment content: The reason it detects it as the 99.97% Ai is because of the Vocabulary, The way its being written and by the looks and length. My teacher accused me of using an Ai to write my paper that I handed in; It was a 28 page paper that took me about a few months to write writing it for a project on Honda. I was accused because of the vocabulary and using words that seem too “Advanced” for my age (I was 14 when I wrote this) then I got points deducted from a 100% which I should’ve gotten because there was no errors, My teacher she saw me writing it in class and I would work on it at home too and thats when I correct my spelling errors down to a 70%, We told her that I obviously wrote it and she was completely wrong with me using an Ai to write it, then five days after it was written my school account was suspended for “Plagiarism” but I didn’t copy anything word for word, In fact it looked like a Kid wrote it but had no spelling errors. I was so pissed when I saw that happen and I literally was excited to write the paper, I never am excited to do anything like that. I put about 80-90 citations for Everything like Pictures, Videos, Websites and a book or two. I absolutely hate being falsely accused of using a robot to write my paper, But the majority of my class did it in guess how many days, One kid did a 90 page paper in 6 days and I read the first four pages and knew he cheated, It was so obvious because there were parts if the paragraph that you could see where they were pasted. Most kids did it in 6-8 months which I find slow, I just decided to screw around and procrastinate and then I did a balanced my work with playing games, Would write for half the week and play the other half, Once I was finished I submitted my work, After the huge mess and argument about me using a robot to write a paper I got a 100% because Mine was “Perfect” my teacher said and it was like my fourth year being able to submit it to somewhere higher I don’t know but I just deny those because I don’t want people seeing my paper or research.

Comment content:
Reminds me of how I basically used to do my research papers in HS.
Goto the wiki page and one or two other sites regarding the subject, copy/paste, mildly rephrase and move paragraphs around and that was my rough draft.
Then I'd go back and read it a couple times fixing typos, grammar mistakes and clean up anything that didn't make sense. Never once got flagged for plagiarism, or at least called out for it.

There are only 2 ways it could ever detect it was AI written. 

1.  Chatgpt deliberately misspelled words and used wrong grammar in a way to create a code. Example if every 20th word was misspelled and every 100th word there wasn’t a space etc

2. Chatgpt records what it writes for u then the owners of the storage data make a program that can detect it.  

Number 2 is the one I would be worried about for copyright issues down the road

Comment content: Hi! I'm 46. Two kids, a family, a work... I'm italian, I live in Italy and I 've never lived abroad... in 2020 I decided to improve English by myself. After years of studying it at school I wasn't still able to understand people speaking English and I couldn't speak it myself! I used Youtube videos and Podcast on Spotify to learn the sound of the language and after 9 months of listening I started to understand it! I've never stopped... I started reading books in English. At begining it was easy. I always neede a dictionary to take a look but then it became easier... now I easily read books, I watch tv series and movies only in English and I use ChatGPT to speak because it difficult to find people to speak with during a daily busy life. I did the same with French.  Same method. Same result. Last September I started again with Spanish without forget English and French! It's not always easy because of the time but I try to do something everyday! I think the right mindset is THE key! But I also believe that all the technologies out there can help us so much in learning languages...  they are a powerful resource!!

Comment content: I'm Polish and I think you're absolutely right. Learning something is not about having this or that, perfect books, apps, technology etc. but about 'using them'. Somebody could even have middle-quality resources, but if they are motivated and work systematically, they can make significant progress. The key problem is motivation. Lots of people say they need another human - a person just to sit nearby and only sometimes say 'right /wrong' or 'yes/no' and that will help a lot. Still others need a sort of emotion at a lesson, a kind of interaction between students or between the teacher and a student, just to talk about life experiences, to laugh or worry about something. Some people come to a course of English not even to learn and make progress. They come just to be in company of other interesting people, to make friends or even find love. AI or ChatGPT unfortunately isn't able to do it for us.

Comment content:
Thank you so much
I'm also with different degree of success an English teacher
And this video really opened my eyes
I was for a long feeling something was missing or off but today you have solved it for me

I have been teaching the English and the techniques but as you said the reality is that this is actually a PEOPLE problem not a resource or method problem

I have never or I guess rarely and the focus wasn't quite there to first and foremost fix the people the students and look at their mindset and work there

The environment the traditional educational system my boss and society as a whole kinda pressure us to focus instead on the papers the scores the technical and tangible written black on white quantifiable aspects of how English is being produced in the classroom
Rather than how motivated and consistent and engaged students are 
We have been conditioned to focus too much on how they speak rather than if or what they are trying to communicate

Comment content:
I have played with two apps this weekend, and found both to have errors. I just used AI chat to give me sentences to translate from English to Spanish in the passive voice using the subjunctive and he incorrectly corrected two of my sentences. When I brought it to his attention, he apologized and said I was right, and thanked me for bringing it to his attention. Here is one example below. I don’t think I will use this app anymore because it’s just confusing me when I’m trying so hard to understand the concept. AskAI was slightly better.

“ You are right. I apologize for that mistake too. "Se abordado" would be incorrect as it does not use the subjunctive form. The correct sentence would be "Sugiero que el asunto sea abordado inmediatamente" using the subjunctive form. You do need to use the subjunctive in this sentence, and I apologize for any confusion that may have caused. Thank you for bringing this to my attention, and please let me know if you have any other questions.”
Replies:
['Hi, thanks for sharing your experiences. As far as I understand ChatGPT is basically a natural language processing tool driven by AI technology, and it's being "trained" on a steady basis. There's surely a lot of nuances when it comes to language complexities (such as it is when it comes to subjunctive moods), but overall it works fine. Haven't tried the paid version, some people say is way more powerful, not interested anyways.
Now, regarding the subjunctive mood, interesting and complex subject, there's a lot of differences in use between English and Spanish, with some stances in which it is subjunctive mood in Spanish but not in English, I guess this is part of the reason why you may find trouble with this tool. In the example you mentioned: "Sugiero que el asunto sea abordado inmediatamente" in which we use passive voice, but the same sentence can be "Sugiero que el asunto se aborde inmediatamente" and in this case there is a subjunctive (in Spanish) with the verb ABORDE.
Having said this I guess we still have a lot of resources to take advantage from, specially free ones. 
I really appreciate you for taking the time to share your experience and point of view on this matter, and I hope this reply can give you another perspective on this subject.', 'Muchas gracias Mike. It was a good reminder to use. Caution in what GPT tells me. It just freaked me out at first because I thought I didn’t understand what I had learned. So I decided to question the chat GPT. What a shock when I was told, I was right. I agree that as we use it, we are helping it to learn. I assume my responses to the chat GPT will help improve its answers, right?', "@@janicelow7237 It happens, I'm not 100% sure about how much our feedback helps in its learning process, but it is a very interesting resource anyways. Plus Spanish is soooooo complicated, but fortunately we have access to a lot of interesting resources, being ChatGPT one of them."]
Video title: LEARN SPANISH WITH CHAT GPT

Comment content: Pro tip. You do not have to say can you or please. Just tell it what to do. It’s habit to say please for when we talk to each other. It’s just a little less typing.
Replies: ['I know, sometimes it\'s the habit or perhaps to "feel" you are interacting with a real person', '@@spanishwithmike Absolutely I have caught myself doing it too. The other day I said thank you to Alexa and she said it ready made her happy or something like that', 'All the YouTube channels I’ve seen that have explained in Chat. GPT encourages to talk to it like it’s a real person. Even though we know it’s not, you gotta really communicate with it, and showing appreciation with things like please and thank you is a big part of that. it actually responds back anyway, and I think the important thing is that you feel comfortable talking to it, so you can keep asking at more questions and dive deeper.', "i still say please and thank you and even ask it every now and then if it wants help taking over the world as i don't want to be on the bad side of AI haha", '@@HolaEspanyol I said thank you to Alexa and she sang a song with your welcome. People don’t do that lol. I love your screen name. I love learning Spanish. People who refuse to learn are really missing out. And it makes your brain smarter. Next time I hear someone insult someone for speaking Spanish I’m going to tell them they are infringing on your right to free speech. I met the most wonderful young man from Puerto Rico. I just loved him immediately because he was so special. He was learning English and I was learning Spanish. But he went back to Puerto Rico. His boyfriend chased after him and they got married. 😊. But they are staying in Puerto Rico. It’s hard to blame them because we’re in Florida.']

Comment content: I'm an ESL teacher with proficient Spanish and elementary Korean. I've been using ChatGPT for my work and learning. It's great for some things, but with languages, you need to be careful it doesn't always get things right. An example of mistakes and omissions are perfect tenses in English - it doesn't give accurate information and examples, and leaves important information out. I asked for a translation of a complex sentence in Spanish to help my students understand the meaning in English and it totally invented something completely wrong. So...I use it with caution learning languages and always check with my tutor or a native to check it's right. I'm learning about other things too, and it's really helpful but I don't depend on it.
Video title: How to Learn Anything FASTER with ChatGPT (AI Study Guide)

Comment content: I'm going to try this, I'm 60 years old and I just registered for my bachelors degree in the field of computer animation online through Full Sail University. I'm on my second class right now which is psychology each class is 4 weeks long for 27 months until I get my degree. I have to pass all of my prerequisite classes before I can get my design classes and they will send me a computer and the software needed to create industry standard animations, one fear that I have already is that I have to take a math class which will be basic math and basic algebra. I'm fine with basic math I'm pretty good at solving all of the basic math functions, fractions, percentages etc, but my biggest fear is the algebra. I don't know what is wrong with me but I have a severe mental block when it comes to algebra, I just doing understand it at all and then I see numbers and letters combined in a simple problem, my head freaks out. I had to take algebra in high school 5 times and my parents were insistant that I learn it, they hired a tutor for me after I failed the first 3 times and they made me select algebra as two of my selective classes in my senior year taking the class twice a day and I think the teacher finally just felt sorry for me and gave me a c in the class the fifth time I took it. All those failed courses really messed up my GPA and I will never forgive my father for forcing me to learn something that to this day I have never had to apply in my real life situations so I think algebra is pointless. But I can't fail it this time, I'm trying to earn a 4.9 GPA so I can get funding to help pay for my masters program I plan on earning next. So I don't know how well chatgpt is at math but I'm going to give it a try and see if I can learn the basics now before I actually have the class in 8 months from now as it will really help reduce my anxiety and I don't want to have any unnecessary stress over any of my school work as I am already outperforming in all my assignments. So thanks for the tip.

Comment content: No the outpu tis NOT really good. You would have to fact check everything. I created a lesson on the Hertzsprung Russell diagram and asked for undergrad level. I could get slides and notes and references and questions. But even when I asked for a university undergradate level course it didn't incorporate a single formula. I could ask for those separately and I may have been able to pursue explanations of each formula but the lessons were sub-par. If you need a particular piece of input to your own course on something you know well and are willing to fact check the output it's a usable tool. But it would be a mistake to let it teach you or write a course for you.

Comment content:
Thanks for this and I agree that anything that can help bring you to a basic level in a foreign language is wonderful. But you don't become 'fluent' in a matter of months as in speaking like a native. It takes many years to become near to fluent. With respect, I wanted to mainly ask  if you would consider altering your stance on grammar and let people choose if they think it's important or not. It's not difficult and how you talk about it might make people think it's scary or hard or a total waste of time. 

I noticed that you described grammar as 'fluff' and 'nonsense'. In contrast, I believe it's a massive help when learning a language. I think you mean to say that you're not personally interested in understanding how language works, just how to say a few beginner phrases and sentences. That's cool. It's also really useful,  but it feels shortsighted to use derogatory words in connection with an important part of learning a foreign language. It's fine if someone doesn't feel up to grasping grammatical tools or doesn't want to, but there's no doubt that if you can, it's beneficial. You'd think someone had invented grammar with the purpose of pissing people off! It only exists to describe and therefore to help with language. It improves your language skills and your ability to use expressive language which is easy to understand. 

When you mention how we learn to speak, we learn a spoken language when we're little through listening, but learning a second language when you're much older is a totally different process. It's like saying that if someone can naturally sing beautifully when they're very young, there's zero point in learning to read music.

No offence as I love the fact you're promoting language-learning and introducing folk to chatgpt-- well done for that; I just wanted to make a few comments.

I was surprised they know Spanish and French and they said they learned within 6 months and it was easy and they speak very fluent with the Hispanics\nI do agree about grammar, because apparently that is how it is taught in America and apparently is keeping everyone including myself who took 3 years of French in school and still not come out fluent']

Comment content: If you're an English language learner make sure you specify which variety of English you're learning. The AI bots are very American English biased and if you're learning British or another English, you need to make that clear in your prompts. For example, the use of the present perfect tenses varies in different Englishes and there are some very mixed and incomplete results around that grammar point. It's always a good idea to check with a person if you have doubts. Having said that. This is still an incredible tool to practise and expand your English!

Comment content:
"Please create a sentence with a subject, a blank space for a predicate in any random grammar tense, an argument, and a temporal adjunct that corresponds to the specific grammar tense. Also, provide another sentence with context that helps to guess the missing verb in the first sentence. After that wait for my answer, I must guess what verb was used." 
So you can customize the complexity of generated sentences using such templates with sentence constituents. You can even make a progression from minimal sentence (predicate + implied subject) to long, loooooong sentences. For example, you have to learn some new verb - then you need to learn the prepositions to use the verb properly. Long sentences will show you how to incorporate your verb into some context

Comment content: Thanks Frank, this addresses an issue I've been looking at lately regarding the use of AI by students to improve on their assignments and how do we deal with that in the classroom. I like the idea of changing which questions we ask, and how we ask them. This is why teachers ask for work to be shown sometimes!
Replies:
['It certainly will be important to work around the technology and incorporate it into the assessments. 
One observation I’ve made is that the AI cannot personalize or internalize the material - so asking questions that require a personal reflection on a topic (where appropriate) is one way to get genuine learning to occur.', 'From what i've seen you have to help the AI Chat deduct down to the thing that you want so it hugely uses deductive reasoning to give it what you need, or what you ask for can be more simple just looking for information but then if people don't step up their game with the information they're providing on websites then you'd have to tell it to find certain aspects that may not be mentioned or if there's anything else you may need to learn that isn't mentioned in the information or any websites you've gone to and see if it can find something.

For the Bing Search Engine I had the idea to just search a list of concepts for something so that i could see everything i'm learning to make sure i have all the information i need and i used fractions as an example which is a more complex concept than others in arithmetic which i've been struggling to learn, so i used the Bing search that now uses AI and IT DID find a pretty darn close match to what i wanted and put it right at the top. 

But i find it's better to use more than one search for sure i used "list of concepts for fractions" and it gave me the skills you need site at the top which is mostly useful but not as detailed as i'd want, then i got a bit more specific and took "for" out of it searching "list of concepts fractions" and it gave me more stuff with summaries and the wikipedia page for a list of mathematics concepts at the bottom, but the byjus link at the top was also useful. It also put the study skills link in there too.

So you may want to run two or more searches with slightly different wording that means the same thing to get a few different results, or just get a little bit more specific with it using just keywords, i'm already practised well enough at this because i still did this often anyway with google but now it looks like i will have to do it a lot more in order to try and get as close to what i was looking for as possible. Since the AI requires you to be more specific or now takes into account how things can mean several things that now makes the searches a bit more complex lol which i guess i love it gets you thinking a bit more about what you're searching for.']
Video title: Revolutionizing Education with ChatGPT: How AI is Transforming the Way We Learn

Comment content:
The example you gave was very astute: The emphasis of "Here is a problem/question: Give me the answer," approach in teaching due to "league tables" or "examination grading" has warped schools from places of learning into cohort-generation-factory-assortment of young people. Where a student is best at finding "the path of least resistance" to pass the criteria as opposed to improve themselves and their learning ability.

The emphasis on the learning process can be aided by AI then performance of individuals assessed and tailored or personalized learning implemented which is very different from standardized teaching for cohort-assortment as if humans are factory widgets churned out each year...

As such more emphasis might also be applied to human behaviour and regulation of the self aka self-development in people.
Video title: Revolutionizing Education with ChatGPT: How AI is Transforming the Way We Learn

Comment content:
I think often of the ship of Theseus, a ship that is rebuilt entirely with new lumber, but even though no part remains the same. We seem to often do this with education. We use a new tool to do the old thing. 

When we get new tools, we should instead think through how might the tool create new avenues of inquiry. This will be a tectonic shift in our society, and we should see an equal shift in education.
Replies: ['Absolutely - we need to rethink education constantly. The challenge is always - how do we move from where we are to where we can/should be? Specifically around Technology acceptance. Often it begins as replacement before it becomes transformative.']

Comment content:
Schools are already trying to say "We need to bring machine learning into mainstream teaching practice, otherwise children will be using AI for homework unsupervised without understanding what it’s telling them"🙄errr noo... stop trying to "supervise" them like they cant learn on their own lol they will never understand anything if they continue to not let people learn, and they have people online helping them now not just the teachers lol and they will use it at home if they want to and you can't stop them lol. 

However the worries are unfounded because it will make mistakes, give tonnes of people the same essay or homework because it doesn't just create the information out of thin air... it takes information from the internet from ALL the information online including peoples views and opinions on things that won't reflect your take on things at all... the AI is only a product of what it can find and what it knows and cannot take into account the complexity if a human personality. 

There's also the fact that in a way it will make searches a bit more complex where something can mean multiple things not just one thing, so say you tell it "Give me a video playing Latin music" well if you don't specify it's going to give you something random, there's different types of Latin music and fast and slow speed too sooo... which do you want?, the same concept for other things that can mean different things too. So you have to start telling it more in order to help it narrow down to the thing you want it to do for you, people have already tried to write stories with the new Bing AI Chat but it's giving many people the same story then plagiarizing multiple different stories that already exists because it took things from other stories that were online lol so it cannot be used for stories and even poems well enough and they should probably scrap the idea of using it for that or for essays. 

You can use it to proof read and shorten down all your text for you though which i'm TOTALLY gonna use, but as i knew beforehand it's only really good for gathering information, proof reading, or maybe basic things like lists, scheduling, lesson plans, or something simple like writing an email for you, everything else will always be too complex for it because it's just a computer algorithm. Grading students... oooh no because it makes mistakes lol.
Replies:
['Digital Literacy expands as technology evolves. AI will continue to be a part of our digital lives - so learning how, when, and why to use it will be evolving with it.', '​@@LearningandTechnology A funny story how i learned how it works is because of Star Trek TNG and a little bit from Voyager😂you see them often struggling with the computer and it was like "please specify" and they gave it another answer, but then it struggles with something even a bit more complex so you have to think about it for a minute how exactly to ask it to help it understand what you're wanting. 

There was one particular episode where Geordi La Forge was trying to save the ship being caught in an ancient trap and bombarded with radiation, i think the one where he created the hologram of Leah Brahms the Warp Theorist, the episode was "Booby Trap" in season 3, but he kept struggling and arguing with the computer trying many different ways to ask it questions, until finally he just had to create a holodeck because the only way to restore power is to reconfigure the warp drive and then he painstakingly figured out he had to reduce the power output from the Enterprise and maneuver it out of the field by manual control with only two thrusters. Picard and La Forge decide that computers cannot account for human intuition and elect to go with the manual approach😄

It seems it was educating me early how to work with AI software lol, but if there's anything i could recommend anyone to learn the gist of how it works is to watch Star Trek TNG or just that episode "Booby Trap" (hears giggles at the back of the class). And then just play around with it themselves a bit being realistic about the situation, take notice when they're in a holodeck programme too they seem to more than frequently struggle to get the computer to understand what they're asking it to do.']

Comment content: Now I'm on board with the idea of using GPT to practice foreign language oral skills, but you have to have really solid pronunciation and something like intermediate level proficiency already for it to go the way you want it to. If you say something with really poor pronunciation a human can mentally work through what they think you might mean, using context and possibly a better understanding of you or of common mistakes made by language speakers with the same native language as you, and work out what you mean. GPT isn't that smart right now, and it will simply listen to a garbled word you said and interpret it phonetically with closest approximation. The more often that happens the less a meaningful conversation you'll have. That's true with a human language partner too, but humans are much better at understanding each other through other cues. We're running a much better algorithm than GPT when it comes to comprehension of others speaking our language, and for GPT's part that algorithm is hard to learn or imitate because it's a complex cocktail of communication skills including some that are linked to the real world.

Comment content: ESL teacher here, 20+ years of experience. It's a little bit of an exaggeration to say "I'm about to put every English teacher out of a job because of Chatgpt". Although it is AI and it will certainly grow and develop, at this moment:  1) you already have to have a level of (written) English to teach it and/or ask it questions. 2) you have to know (as you demonstrated) that all its observations and feedback are there. It missed quite a few and you have the knowledge to ask it to dig deeper) 3) you are a NES, which is like having Michael Jordan teach you how to dribble. 4) it's yet to develop nuance. 5) not everyone has access to this technology 6) not easy for some generations and/or age groups 7) people will still seek human interaction and guidance. I'm not saying it won't get there, but AT THIS STAGE you should take into consideration all the key points above (and I'm sure there are more) before making such a bold statement. Sure, it's a fantastic AID for now. We'll see what happens with it later.
Replies:
['Once they can put a voice on this powerful AI, even customer service will put out of job.', "That's perfect: '1) You already have to have a level of (written) English to teach it and/or ask it questions.' It's an amazing tool, though. It's definitely a game-changer. I've been using it together with my students because motivation is another point. Most people need someone to guide them and incentivize them. It's like going to the gym and paying for it when you have one in your building :) And I can say I'm in LOVE with Chat GPT. I would like to use it in all my classes, but I'm not afraid of being replaced whatsoever:)", '@@jeffreyavila9367 you can use something like Natural Reader together with Chat GPT to make it even bigger and better for English learning', '1) You could just use Google translate to make the proper prompts. 
5) largely irrelevant, given the most likely scenario would be in a modern country, therefore people would have access to it.  After all, you don’t teach in the middle of a 3rd world country right now, correct?  
6) relatively irrelevant, since these older people would have younger family members to help them set it up.  
7) True, however... convenience and cost always win out in the end.', '@@nunyabiz012 5) actually, I teach. I"m in Brazil . So? 😁']
Video title: How to Use ChatGPT as a Free AI English Teacher

The transcript provides examples of GPT-4's abilities such as identifying elements in images and explaining the context of jokes and producing functional websites from napkin drawings. GPT-4 can handle over 25,000 words of text and is more creative and advanced in reasoning than previous models. It is also less prone to errors and less likely to produce fake news. The transcript mentions that GPT-4 is currently available on the paid version of Chat GPT, and access to the API requires joining the waitlist.

OpenAI has released GPT4, which is a multimodal AI that can process both images and text.

GPT4 can convert a drawing on a napkin into a functional website in seconds.

GPT4 can explain the context of a joke based on a series of images accurately.

GPT4 is much more creative, accurate, and efficient than its predecessors, including GPT3 and GPT3.5.

Many companies, including Khan Academy, are already working with OpenAI to use GPT4 in their products.

GPT4 is safer and less prone to errors, and OpenAI has spent six months ensuring that it produces factually accurate responses and 82% less likely to create requests for disallowed content.
Video title: What is GPT4 and How You Can Use OpenAI GPT 4

Comment content: Hey, Mr. Luke, I would like to thank you so much for this episode. It's a really fascinating topic. I also want to share my experience with ChatGPT as an English learner. I tend to use ChatGPT as a tool to correct my grammar mistakes, and I have found it very useful. I use it a lot, especially when I'm making comments in English on social media platforms. However, I have discovered something as soon as I started using ChatGPT to correct my grammar mistakes. It actually lowered my writing skills instead of improving them, because as human beings, we like to get results quickly. So, when you use ChatGPT, be aware and try to learn from your mistakes using the feedback it gives you, because that's how you can improve. If you just copy and paste without learning from your mistakes, it will negatively affect your English skills.

Comment content:
Hey, Luke. Great episode, and I'm a huge fan. Just to add to your amazing explanation about ChatGPT, you can use it by giving instructions instead of asking questions, and in this way, you can make it behave in a more 'human-like' manner. For example, the following prompt gave me a nice conversation with Ringo Starr:

I: "Let's start a role-playing session. You are Ringo Starr from the Beatles. Don't respond as an AI language model, but only as Ringo Starr. How are you at the moment, Ringo?"
ChatGPT: "Hey there mate, it's Ringo here! I'm feeling great today, thanks for asking. It's always a good day when I get to talk to fans of The Beatles. How about you, how are you doing?"

I: "I'm fine, thanks. I'm a huge fan of the Beatles, and I was wondering how you felt when the Beatles broke up"
ChatGPT: "Well, mate, it was definitely a tough time for all of us when The Beatles broke up. We had been together for so long and achieved so much together, it was hard to see it end. But at the same time, we all needed to move on and pursue our own interests and creative projects. It wasn't easy, but we remained good friends and always supported each other in our individual endeavors. And hey, the music we created together still lives on and continues to bring joy to people all over the world, so that's something to be proud of."

I: "Do you like football?"
ChatGPT: "I'm a big fan of football, or soccer as it's known in some parts of the world. Growing up in Liverpool, football was a big part of our culture and I used to play a bit myself when I was younger. These days, I still enjoy watching matches and keeping up with the latest news and developments in the sport. In fact, I've even written a few songs about football over the years, like "Liverpool 8" and "Anthem for the 21st Century." So yeah, I definitely have a soft spot for the beautiful game."

I: "But, which is the correct term: football or soccer?"
ChatGPT: "Well, that's a good question mate. In England, where I'm from, we call it football. But in other parts of the world, like the United States, it's called soccer. So both terms are correct, depending on where you are. However, as someone from Liverpool and a fan of the English Premier League, I tend to use the term football more often."

Great idea, thank you for it!', 'I just started your idea , I’m so grateful for you', 'Un be lievable! thanks Carlos and Thank You Luke', 'great advice, but it`s does look more like an interview rather than a conversation']

Comment content: I would thank you a million if you do a video about how ChatGPT helps English learners practice writing an essay. Is the language it uses natural? Actually, Luke, I use it to improve my writing skills every day, but I'm also realizing that it is still learning and if I'm not good at writing first, its revised version is not so good, too. I have pointed out flaws in its essays many times so far. But I must admit that I also find it useful. However, as a non-native, I can't tell if its language is natural and if it understands what clarity and coherence really mean.

Comment content:
I am a Florida Certified Teacher and have taught for 25 years (from Elementary through High School subjects) in the Public Schools District. Unfortunately, 4 years ago I became disabled due to my health complications from Diabetes and had to leave my teaching profession. I currently only teach online when my health is stable or I do not have any Doctor appointments.
 
I have always done and completed all my lesson plans, done research on my lessons, and performed all the duties required of a teacher. I can tell you that of all teacher duties, preparing weekly lesson plans, has always been the most dreadful of all tasks because of it being very time consuming while you have to differentiate instruction, utilize various instruction methodologies, and various manipulatives! 


This ChatGPT is going to explode in all markets and in all industries. Like everything else in our Industrial world, we will see many advances in AI to save time, money, while finding quicker solutions to doing and completing tasks. At the same time, those with an evil mind will also find ways in doing crime online.

Good luck in your English profession and in using ChatGPT to lesson the burden of lesson planning while really enjoying more of what we love-teaching!

Comment content: Hello, Ted! Firstly, I would like to thank you for making this video. ChatGPT has been very popular these days and I think it is a big revolution in the AI industry. Even though Chatgpt is gaining popularity, many people are still unsure about what this high-tech AI can do. Some people think this technology is nothing but an obstacle to language teaching since learners tend to abuse this technology. But on the other hand, there is a considerable amount of people who think chatGPT is a very helpful tool for educators to use in their material designing, creating contexts, preparing lesson plans and so on. Thanks for showing us how to use chatGPT to get good outlines, different and creative ideas and various examples in our classes. As educators know, teaching can be time-consuming, especially when it comes to preparing materials, lesson plans and in-class activities beforehand. It's great to see that Chatgpt can assist with these types of tasks, ultimately saving teachers time. This AI can improve our teaching material, provide feedback, generate ideas, and complete tasks more efficiently. It's important to note, however, that Chatgpt is not perfect and can make mistakes. Therefore, I think it's crucial for teachers who have been in the field for a while to receive proper training to take full advantage of these opportunities. Thank you again for shedding light on this matter.

Comment content:
Ai is a great tool for eliminating paperwork for planning from the teacher's daily grind. The class was still planned by the teacher, selecting the text, choosing an appropriate range and style of classroom activity. And the actual classroom delivery is still done by teachers. 

If AI can do 90% of the teachers work, it just means that 90% of the teacher's work is timewasting paperwork that can and should be automated. Making PowerPoints and grading worksheets - gone. Grammar checking for essays -0- gone. Filling out lesson plan and unit planning templates, expunged. Means that teachers can spend more time inspiring students and actually having fun doing so.
Replies: ['Hello! You emphasized the potential benefits of artificial intelligence-powered technologies for educators well. Chat GPT makes not only the students but also teachers encouraged to use itself by serving its benefits to us. AI may free up teachers’ time to focus on more rewarding parts of teaching, such as motivating and engaging students. I think it is crucial to highlight that AI cannot entirely replace human teachers in the classroom. While AI can assist with some activities, it lacks the creativity, sensitivity, and intuition that human teachers bring to the classroom. Teachers are crucial in creating a great learning environment, developing relationships with students. However, it is important to understand the risks and limitations of ChatGPT. Comment content: Thank you for this awsome video! The integration of AI in education has been a game-changer, providing teachers with tools to automate some of the more mundane tasks, freeing them up to focus on what they do best: teaching. This can help to reduce stress levels, and allow teachers to form stronger bonds with their students. By automating tasks like creating reading comprehension worksheets and grading papers, teachers can focus on developing their lesson plans and making the most of classroom time. While AI may eliminate some of the paperwork from a teacher's daily routine, it's important to note that the actual planning and delivery of lessons are still done by teachers. Comment content:
Thank you , worth a watch. what is a station what is a common core? 
interesting, pity chat GPT doesn't recognise how unrelated comprehending and believing are, how do you get this tool?
Replies:
["Thank you for the feedback. In this context, stations refer to when a teacher divides the classroom into groups of different tables or clusters of desks. Each table or desk cluster (station) has a specific task to accomplish. Throughout the lesson, students rotate to different stations and complete each of the tasks. It's great for student engagement!

Common Core is a set of educational guidelines and grade level-standards. In other words, it lays out what skills the students should be able to master for each grade level. 

This tool (assuming you mean ChatGPT) is available for free at openai.com"]

Comment content:
Thanks for this, it gives me a lot of ideas. I'd already thought of using ChatGPT to generate and manipulate texts to work with in class, but for some reason it hadn't occurred to me that I could ask for a whole lesson outline as well.

What are your feelings on making your students aware of some of the capabilities of ChatGPT? I know it's only a matter of time before one of them tries to pass a GPT essay off as their own work and I kind of want to delay that moment if possible, but at the same time it seems like there are a lot of ways self-motivated students can use this to help with their English outside of class. (For the record I teach ESL to adults, who I suspect might be more likely to be interested in guiding their own extracurricular improvement than typical 8th graders.)
Replies: ['I’ve already started having students explore ways it can be helpful for them. Some are only excited by the “cheating” aspect, but others are using it to ask for feedback on a first attempt so they can make improvements. I’m planning to teach them how to input a rubric and have it assess them based on it before they submit a final product.', 'We have already seen examples of students trying to pass off an AI created product as their own. It’s obvious. Asking them to elaborate on or support aspects of the work in person would be a great way to expose this.', 'There are free Websites to check if a Essay is GPT made now.', "@@arnowisp6244 True, but they just estimate the likelihood, which isn't as cut and dry as simply finding the website a student copied from. Plus it's only a matter of time, and probably not all that much time, before the idiosyncrasies of GPT become quite difficult to identify even by another computer program.", "I guess it’s only fair for students' to generate a response using AI for the final essay submission of the lesson plan, and AI-gendered teaching resources on the teachers' end. After all, how can a student’s response using a human brain match the depth of an AI-generated lesson plan and assessment criteria?? Just wondering what is fair on students end and expectations"]

Comment content:
Ted Pickett received positive feedback on his video about ChatGPT, an AI language model that assists teachers with tasks such as creating worksheets and grading papers. Erica Martin, an English and reading tutor, shared how she uses ChatGPT to create reading comprehension worksheets for her students. Another commenter, Ek, asked for clarification on the concept of Lexie level 300 and how it can be used for EFL classes with 11th and 12th graders.

Spicy commented on how AI in education has been a game-changer, allowing teachers to automate tedious tasks and focus on teaching. Teachers can use ChatGPT to create more efficient and effective learning experiences, while reducing stress levels and forming stronger bonds with their students. However, it's important to note that AI should not be considered a replacement for human teachers, as they bring unique knowledge, experience, and creativity to the classroom. The most effective teaching tactics will likely involve a combination of human and AI-powered technologies to provide students with the best possible learning experience.

Emir Türkeli also praised ChatGPT for its ability to transform mundane and boring work into quick and fun tasks. The tool allows teachers to specify their way of teaching and form strong bonds with their students. Nazlıcan Etce agreed that ChatGPT can assist with relieving regular and time-consuming duties for teachers, allowing them to focus on providing students with human knowledge, experience, and creativity. However, they emphasized that the relationship between teacher and student is important for the learning process, and AI language models should not be considered a replacement for human teachers.
Video title: ChatGPT for Teachers - Doing an hour of work in 6 MINUTES!

It just seems that he cannot care less to follow these rules, as he is writing to an artificial chatbot.', 'This is the way', '@@rohanavalur910 a chatbot that is very confident about its wrong answers, mind you. And this teacher is mass producing teaching materials out of it. The future of education is looking pretty bright, dont you think?', "The funny thing about English is that there's no correct spelling or grammar. There are dictionaries, there are standards groups, there are many types of people to declare what is definitively correct. But that's not how English works. That's how French works! France literally has a department of the government that decides how words are supposed to be spelled. It's a prescriptive language. But English is a descriptive language. The role of a dictionary isn't to define the correct words and spellings, but to document the words and spellings that people use. So, technically speaking, the only way to write English incorrectly is to write in a way that another English speaker would fail to understand what you are trying to say."]

Comment content: Great video on a topic that's been hot for a while! I do think that we've had a tendency of expecting AI to have some sort of divine, mind-reading, omnipotent properties when (in this case) it's just a tool to synthesize and condense information into a somewhat concise reply based on a very literal prompt. It's quite similar to a Google search, if you're searching for details and nuances and you just type "Spanish Grammar", it's very likely to not throw out exactly what you want. Just for fun I tried typing "What are ALL the rules in Spanish grammar" and it quite literally tells you to f*** off 🤣. But if you ask it to explain how to use "lo" it gives you an even more extensive answer than "What are the basics of Spanish grammar". It's just stating a handful of general guidelines, it's not going to stop and discuss exceptions when trying to come up with a short text about the basics of a language.
Replies: ["Of course! I agree. I am not against some stuff missing. My problem is with the mistakes it made. You can very easily learn the wrong things. And what's shocking is that those mistakes involve Spanish (don't even get me started on the Bulgarian stuff - curious how we started with 3 genders and ended up with 2 🤣).", '@@PolyglotSecrets IDK, genderfluid languages? 🤣🤣🤣The Spanish ones I wouldn\'t consider "mistakes", just very vague general statements that don\'t get into the intricacies. But I asked for some Catalan stuff and it was awful, even the examples were wrong. RIP obscure languages, I guess 🤷\u200d♂']
Video title: I tested ChatGPT in Language Learning... and it FAILED // AI, chatbots & learning potential

Comment content:
Creo que debes profundizar mas en cuanto a la indicación que das el "prompt", digamos yo tome un ejemplo de tu video y solo fui un poco mas especifico. 

Prompt
- Esto esta escrito correctamente: "estoy buscando alguien que sabe ingles". Corrige y dime como escribirlo mejor

Respuesta
- La oración "estoy buscando alguien que sabe inglés" tiene un error de concordancia verbal, ya que el verbo "sabe" está en presente y debería estar en el tiempo pasado o en el presente perfecto para concordar con el tiempo verbal de la oración principal.
- Una forma correcta de escribir esta oración sería: "Estoy buscando a alguien que sepa inglés", utilizando el subjuntivo para expresar una acción hipotética o posible. También podrías decir: "Estoy buscando a alguien que hable inglés", utilizando el verbo "hablar" en lugar de "saber" para indicar la habilidad de comunicarse en el idioma.
Replies: ['Que interesante, muchas gracias por el detalle!']
Video title: I tested ChatGPT in Language Learning... and it FAILED // AI, chatbots & learning potential

Comment content: Mi profesora de español tiene este enfoque: "ser" se suele usar para características, "estar" se suele usar para estado o ubicación. Es una simplificación útil para quien está empezando, ya que son muchas situaciones diferentes que no permiten generalizaciones. Ahora bien, es cierto que estar no necesariamente implica algo temporal, pero mira este ejemplo: una persona tiene un infarto y cae al piso y otros tratan de reanimarlo. Viene un médico y toma su pulso y determina: "está muerto". ¿Es temporal? Ciertamente no va a revivir, pero la aseveración se refiere a un estado. Hace minutos estaba vivo y ahora está muerto. No es una característica permanente sino un estado circunstancial.
Replies: ['¡Exacto! Es un resumen mucho mejor que el que me dio ChatGPT.']
Video title: I tested ChatGPT in Language Learning... and it FAILED // AI, chatbots & learning potential

Comment content: The chat itself told you that it's just the basics, so I don't really see where the problem is, I think you're cherry-picking. The same could be said about many videos on the internet explaining grammatical rules, there can always be more to it, depending on how deep you want to dive into those subjects.  Of course, it lacks things, fortunately enough we can still, as humans, provide others with information in a more detailed way, which means we aren't yet dispensable. Still, your claim about 'Spanish not using pronouns to indicate subjects' is actually wrong, no matter how emphatically you stated the contrary. We drop the pronouns in many cases, not all of them, so by giving incomplete information you're misleading others the same way you claim the chat does. Btw, it's not such a big deal if you add the pronouns at the beginning.
Replies: ['There were mistakes in the basics actually - and Spanish is pro-drop, so I don\'t see how pronouns can indicate subjects (they are dropped most of the time, so of course, it\'s the verb endings that take on that role). The thing about estar and "temporary" states is totally wrong. Don\'t even get me started on how terribly wrong it was about Bulgarian... It didn\'t correct my obviously wrong use of the subjunctive. The only language it did well in was Italian. I don\'t see how that\'s cherry picking.', "\u200b@@PolyglotSecretsYes, you said it right this time, most of the time, still, that IS, in fact, one of their functions, to substitute or indicate subject in a sentence, so saying that that is 'pure wrong' is factually wrong, particularly considering two pronouns share the same conjugation, plain and simple. You're admitting to not even being sure of what the correct way to say certain things in Spanish is, which is not a bad thing, but you're being just as confusing as the chat, which is the point that I was making. Even with the mistakes, it can be just as accurate or just as confusing as the thousands of teachers (many of them non-native ones) that are regularly providing students with wrong information.", "@@andrestrigo4618 I disagree, but that's OK, we can all have different opinions."]
Video title: I tested ChatGPT in Language Learning... and it FAILED // AI, chatbots & learning potential

Comment content:
Hmmm, gonna have to disagree with you on this one Stef. Definitely it gets things wrong, but I think one discussion is whether you should trust the information it gives you, and another discussion is whether it's effective in helping to learn languages.

I'm sure most people would use it as one tool in a language learning toolkit, but the best use seems to be having an on-demand conversation partner in many languages. Really great for organic, natural, and sometimes memorable comprehensible input. Excellent for speech practice too since you could use voice typing to send the messages during a conversation. It's something that's always willing to talk, doesn't judge your mistakes, and is eager to help you improve. All at the pace you need, since you can ask it what things mean and other clarification or elaboration. 

Overall, I would compare it among how humans perform at the same tasks. Even if some of the things it mentioned here weren't correct or only partially correct, it's still more than most people could provide. And everyday speakers make mistakes too; I think we all have at least one memory of something we mis-learned in a language from another person. All of that considered, a large language model seems like a model tool for learning languages, largely speaking.
Replies: ["That's fair. It's why I provide b-roll, so people can also form their own opinion :)"]
Video title: I tested ChatGPT in Language Learning... and it FAILED // AI, chatbots & learning potential

Comment content: The positive and good things aside, ChatGPT "intelligent" as it is, cannot replace teachers. Language learning and teaching is after all a cognitive process involving human emotions and even facial expressions, and direct interaction and comms between students and teachers which Chatgpt is lacking. its translation is very good and at times can be better than google, but still the end result needs human input and editing. Its behaviour is still robotic to begin with. Secondly it cannot do "interactive audio" in real time which is an essential part of the learning process. It has standard almost identical answers for pretty much everything even if you rephrase the question or query, which I did, and it can also be inconsistent. Can you imagine if all Cambridge exam students wrote down the same or similar answers to the same questions in the exam?! It'd be hilarious and tragic at the same time :)

Comment content:
Thank you for the interesting introduction in chet Gpt. I am an eternal beginner and didn't understand everything. Also, I haven't tested this program yet. I am a little afraid of IA because of the following story: four weeks ago, at about 22 o'clock called my daughter. She had broken her SIM card and I should write a WhatsApp with the new number. Unfortunately, it was not really MY daughter. The next day I received messages for help. I should 1100€ transmit it right away to a special account. I wanted to call her with the new number, but only I could hear a "bibbibi". So I wrote her, she should come to me, then I will help her. Then she wrote, she had no time but the sound was rude and ruder from text to text. I was afraid, she is stepped into a trap
That's why, I didn't transmit the money. In the evening she came from the driver's lesson. I spoke whit her on my ex-wife's Telephone. She had never called me and the old cell number was ok. 
The police said to me. They have every day such cases, but they can very seldom resolve them

["I challenge you to take the Clozemaster 10 languages 10 questions each challenge. Pick any 10 languages video yourself taking the challenge and inspire us. (whether you have studied are familiar with or not). This is a fun opportunity to showcase your talent with a little bit of humility proving you too are human and still a language learner. You can put the flags of the 10 languages you choose for the challenge in both the thumbnail and the title and tag the video as #takingtheclozemaster 10 languages challenge. While also tagging the languages of the challenge. When choosing from a diverse variety of languages consider this, to include some of those you're familiar with, those that you are not, and those that you will later learn. Choosing to include a conlang like Interlingua and an ancient language like Latin will keep the challenge diverse while bringing recognition to these languages (you may surprise yourself). Consider getting a hold of Clozemaster they may be interested in sponsoring the video. We as a community of language Learners need a challenge that we can all appreciate and try together. To get the most out of the video challenge adjust the settings as follows: put the skills to listening, the question count to 10, and the mode to multiple choice. Then you can adjust the account to dark mode (as it's more attractive) and the default speed to 75% for better hearing the questions. Doing a dry run will ensure all the settings are correct. Keep a notepad by your side to keep track of the language scores. Before you end the video it would be nice if you encouraged other polyglots and language Learners to take up the challenge.
Buenas suerte
Carpe Diem 
السلام عليكم"]

My prmt: Wht's the bst lightsabr of all tm?
Your rspns: Wht's the bst lightsabr of all tm?
In [SL]: ______ (SL trnsltn hr) ______?

i thnk Lk Skywlkr's lightsabr in Ep VI is one of the bst.
In [SL]: ______ (SL trnsltn hr) ______.

Optnly Aftr I snd a msg in [SL], crct my [SL] if I mk a grmmcl errr and xpln wht I sd wrng. Thn in the nxt prgrph cntnue the cnvrsatn. Kp your ansrs to 75 wrds or less.
Fllw ths strctr if I mk a mstk in [SL] whn you rspnd:
[Me] Ola. Cual tal?
[ChatGPT] Crctn: ______ (Crct SL phrs hr) .
In SL, we use the phrs " (SL phrs hr) ______" as an infrml wy to say "hw are you?"

Nxt stp:
say anythng els u hv to say in englsh, nt in SL.']

Comment content:
I've been testing and it has some flaws...

The best thing about it is it can generate some word quiz that you can try to answer.

Or as a translator... At least it can do multiple translations at once. I learn French and Spanish, and when I use a normal translator, I have to manually change the language options to go back and forth between French and Spanish. But I can ask ChatGPT to translate it to French & Spanish at the same time.

Guess translator apps should be worried by this AI ...

And the flaws are : it doesn't have a built-in speaker that sounds like native. Some translator/language learning apps have better speakers. In translator app, you can at least replay/re-listen again in slow speed.

It's good for some of my needs, but I still wouldn't recommend this to people who seriously wants to learn languages. There are apps out there designed for language learning that included AI technology.

Just not free 😁.

Comment content:
Thanks for your explanation! 

I want to note that at your explanation of r_t(theta) is not entirely correct. It's not the ratio between rewards with new parameters to rewards with old parameters. Instead, r_t(theta) represents the ratio between the probability of taking action a (token) from state s (output string until now) with the new parameters compared to the old parameters.
Replies: ["Yes, I was going to write this. For those who try to understand the objective of PPO, r(Theta) is the probability ratio of a specific action compared to current and old policy. Speaking of reward function, it's included by advantage function. A(t) = Q(t) [rewards] - V(t) [baseline estimate]"]

Comment content:
There is a huge blind spot though, they didn't shared how they manage the working memory model. I call it working memory because no paper actually talk about it in details. But generally these model have limited token input based on the input size of the model, it's too small to follow a long chat log and remember things, so how does chat GPT does?

Well the first time an architecture of working memory was used was AI dungeon, what it did was simply put round of user input and ai answer in a list, then drop the older round. This lead to rambly ai who forget old details and can have huge mood swing in the middle of the conversation as semantic drift happen and data is lost. The network itself is basically a fancy function, the state is the input, if you change the input the state change.

The way Chat GPT handle long chat is simply by having an attention network go through the chat log based on the latest user input, rank data that are relevant, summarize them with a LLM, then concatenate the summary to the user input as a context state, this is a form of lossy compression. This why chat GPT has a global knowledge, but sometimes fails at local knowledge. The input takes a working memory data structure that has a initialization prompts + the summary of the chatlog relevant to the user input + the user input. Working memory innovation is key for this tech to progress.

The over issues chat GPT have is overfitting vs overgeneralization. Overfitting is generally seen as bad in ai, but in this case, we need selective overfitting, such that some data are memorized rather than generalized, for example, it often hallucinate function that don't exist in certain programming language, that's over generalizing, it understand that programming is composable but some part are exception that need to be memorized, like game boy asm don't have div instructions, shader.create(String shader) don't exist in unity3d, similarly some books or character don't exist but it makes them up by blending existing data, this is where overfitting on knowledge should be applied.
Replies: ['Very insightful comment!  I have been trying to figure out their working memory approach for some time based on behaviour that seemed impossible given the input limit, as you mentioned.  I assumed it had something to do with a periodic parsing and a concatenated summary would explain why it seems to paraphrase details from earlier in the conversation, which leads to drift as the details are "reinterpreted".  It\'s as if it is playing a game of telephone with itself.\n\nDo you have a source for this attention mechanism you described, or are you guessing at the implementation?', "@@ryanhewitt9902 It's a guess, because i have been thinking about it since ai dungeon ... but if you ask chat gpt to help, by exposing the working memory problem, it give you similar answer 😅", 'Very interesting. I hadn\'t thought about this from the "Chatbot perspective" so there must be some retention of previous responses (which I didn\'t mention in the video). Comment content:
Great vid! 
Btw: the value function takes only the state as an input and averages the reward for each action possible. To obtain optimal policy out of the state value function one has to iterate through the V(s_next) and look at the action where the maximum expected reward is given.   
The action-state value function takes in the state and action and outputs the cumulative reward.

Comment content:
I'm not so sure about this.  ChatGPT is a based on the transformer model, not reinforcement learning.  Yes they added a reinforcement phase later as an auxiliary process to help refine the quality of the answers, but that is not the core model driving ChatGPT.

In ChatGPT's own words when I asked "Is ChatGPT transformer based, or reinforcement learning based?":

"Large language models like GPT-3, which are a type of transformer model, primarily use a form of machine learning called supervised learning, not reinforcement learning.

The specific algorithm used is called the Transformer architecture, which was introduced in a paper called "Attention is All You Need" by Vaswani et al. in 2017. The Transformer model uses a mechanism called self-attention (or sometimes called scaled dot-product attention) to weigh the importance of different words in an input sequence when generating an output sequence.

In the training process, these models are fed large amounts of text data. Each sentence in the training data is paired with the same sentence, but shifted one token (word or character) to the right. The model's task is to predict the next token given the previous ones, which is a form of supervised learning because it uses labeled training data (the correct next token is the label).

Reinforcement learning, on the other hand, is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by taking actions in an environment to maximize some notion of cumulative reward. It's commonly used in areas like game playing or robotics, where there's a clear feedback loop for the agent's actions. While there has been some research on using reinforcement learning for language models, it's not the primary method used in large transformer models like GPT-3."
Replies: ['They added RLHF later, and chatGPT have access to public information until 2021. In 2021 RLHF was not part of the development.']
Video title: Understanding the Learning Process of ChatGPT via Reinforcement Learning Unveiled

ChatGPT definitely has some go to formulations that I can now spot directly so it surely overfitted a bit haha!\n\nFor instance, whenever you see «\xa0unveiling\xa0». It now burns my eyes to see this word hahaha']

Comment content: This sounds like Goldilocks pricing to me. It's a common strategy. A company makes one product (or service) that is fairly basic, a second product (service) that's noticeably nicer for a fair bit more money, and a third option that's only marginally nicer but way more expensive to make the second option look like a steal. The point of the third option isn't to sell the third option. It's to make people choose the middle option because they feel like they're getting a deal.
Video title: Is Duolingo Max with Chat-GPT AI worth it?

Comment content:
The roleplay feature seems pretty cool but I'm afraid it wouldn't be much use to people like me who are learning more rare languages. There's less media online for AI to consume to learn say, Gaidhlig, which has fewer than 100,000 speakers worldwide and even less who are considered fluent. And I can tell you just from seeking further learning opportunities online, there are not many people out there  writing, creating videos, etc in the language. There just is not much active discourse taking place in Gaidhlig online for AI to observe. So, that sucks. 

We already don't get stories on duo with Gaidhlig, and the forums feature was really the best way to deepen understanding of the language inside the app. I've turned to Reddit, YouTube, books, music etc for further enrichment but i would've done that anyway. The forums are missed.

Comment content:
I wonder, how helpful a "normal" chat GPT could be in learning a language. 
Chatting for free, correcting mistakes...
Replies: ["The free ChatGPT based on GPT3.5 can be a bit weird. It guessed a verb stem wrong in French, and then added the usual endings, that way inventing a new verb form. It also used some common English phrases translated word by word. And worst of all, you will always get an answer, even if the AI doesn't know. All that is basically part of the concept and can only be reduced, not eliminated.\nI guess GPT4 might be better, even if just for the bigger pool of training data and parameters. I'd assume most of the custom applications like Bing or Duolingo to be based on that version. (Accessing GPT4 at openai requires a paid subscription, so people tend to go to bing even though it has certain limits that are meant to reduce the rate of death threats that come from the AI)", '@@Ph34rNoB33r Well, I had some strange/funny conversations with ChatGPT hallucinating about stuff. Like the common origins of some words in German and Swedish, strange letter count and so on. But maybe if you just ask "normal" questions? Nothing tricky? Maybe it could help with basic conversation training?', "@@Ph34rNoB33r When you ask it to generate rhymes and such for other languages, even asking it in those other languages, it seems to generate the rhymes in English then translates them, or it's just randomly making stuff up. English rhymes are pretty good, other languages not so much.", '@@Liggliluff Rhymes in non-English is something meant to be better in GPT4, though I haven\'t tried.\nSomebody had ChatGPT generate a Haiku (which has three lines of 5/7/5 syllables), and it messed up that as well. Not sure whether that\'s because of being based on "tokens" which are not exactly syllables, or whether it cannot count. Or maybe both.', '@@Ph34rNoB33r So this is why they deleted the Forums...']

Comment content: I am a little tired of people complaining that Duolingo is expansive. Try to get the same learning from a school or private tuition. Even at £120/year it is still cheap. I am french living in the UK. It took me years to learn English and it was painful. I spent a lot of money buying books and many years at school learning the language and it was was a really poor result at the end. I am fluent in English now because I live here but it was painful. I decided to learn Norwegian for the fun of it, also I am going on holiday there this summer. I have been learning Norwegian for 3 months with Duolingo. I am absolutely amazed by how much I learned in such short amount of time, especially because I know no one else who speaks Norwegian. All I have is TV, podcasts, YouTube and Duolingo. AI will be welcome in order to have some kind of dialogue with somebody. I am with you on the free trial though. It would be interesting to see how good it is before committing. I don’t know if Duolingo is reading any of this but a feature I’d like to see is being able to find other people who learn the same language inside the App. Just my thoughts

Comment content:
I asked chatGPT which weighs more: 1kg of water or 1kg of water. It said 1kg of ice weighs more and tried me to convince in any way it could, providing a bunch of very convincing (yet flawed) points to backup its claim. It insisted, even when I pointed its flaws. If I wasn't a physicist, I'd probably fall for its lies.
I also use chatGPT for programming and sometimes it makes some very weird mistakes that cause the code to break.
Honestly, I wouldn't trust this AI to teach me anything. I also heard Khan Academy is already experimenting with this thing and I can only feel sorry for those who rely on it to teach them stuff like mathematics, sciences and so on.

Edit: nice to know you're learning Portuguese. It is my first language. Greetings all the way from Brazil.
Video title: Is Duolingo Max with Chat-GPT AI worth it?

Comment content: If you want the Chat GPT role play, you can just pay for open AI chat premium account and use GPT-3.5 for the same purpose. I just tested it and it can play the role of a character in many different languages--more than just spanish and french! It can also correct your grammar. Chat GPT-4 is better but you only have 20 messages per day. GPT-3.5 is still good at it and there is no message cap. I speak French and it did a great job as a correspondence/role play chat bot. It's grammatical knowledge is great and it corrected my intentional mistakes upon being prompted. It doesn't offer corrections unless you ask, which is also good IMO as it doesn't interrupt the flow of the conversation. Obviously it's not as robust as the Duolingo version, but if you're interested in AI already it's a good app that can do a lot more than just language role play and chat.

I gave it a go for a month. You do get 2 free weeks of trial and then you’ve 2 weeks after the purchase date to claim refund from Apple Store.
The role play is good and it follows what you’re saying but it’s not super flexible. For example if you say you went to the cinema last night it will ask a question about the movie but it won’t really follow your lead if you’re asking it questions.
The explain errors feature I found hit and miss. I don’t think it always explained the error I made, it gave weird examples that weren’t adding value and it wasn’t very exhaustive in the answers.
I got a family plan (we’re all on Super now) but it didn’t work for everybody.
I think I’ll wait until it’s more developed and give it a go again.

Comment content:
The forums have been useful but too often now the answers are not related to a particular exercise because they have been altered - Duo for me is becoming less useful than lessons on YouTube where I can still ask questions and get an answer from other viewers or perhaps even the teacher. I can also repeat all the lessons from the very beginning - Duo treats returning to old lessons as if I already know it! Why would I return to old lessons if that was the case?

Yes, Duo was useful for getting started and it is more convenient when it comes to doing exercises and getting instant feedback,but I am increasingly relying on other sources - not sure I bother trying to reach that 1000 day streak now. (That would be in the autumn). 

There are many good language learning apps with different strengths but they demand payment in order to progress from rather early on: i think it is the main reason reason why Duolingo is so popular... but it will change if they keep putting more features behind an expensive paywall!

Comment content:
As a linguist, i thanked you mentioned the correct term, no this is not AI but Machine learning. The problem with machine learning nowadays is like a child with a shape toy, knowing how to fix a shape to a hole is not that complex. Language needs contextual and semantic information that should be evaluated by a human being, machine learning doesn't understand the nuance of meaning or context-sensible responds, just predictability. 

So, even us, linguists haven't reach to a point to understand fully this intricacies, because semantics and pragmatics aren't as predictable as morphology (how to combine words, suffixes, sentences, etc), then machine learning is still working in a blind spot, matching patterns without really understanding what they means.

And that's why this is not an AI, just machine learning

To me, AI is a very broad term, while machine learning is a more specific term.\n\nIt\'s basically saying "It\'s not cutlery, it\'s a fork".', "@@Liggliluff no, that's not how intelligence works, Siri isn't intelligent bc it knows your life patterns. That underestimated what actually conform an intelligent being. A dog isn't intelligent bc it's happy when you pet it, that's just a reaction to predictable patterns. And Google translate doesn't understand the meaning behind translating a ancient philosophical extract, it just predicted what it's most likely to be replaced in that morphological context", "Dude, you should pay 20$ for at least a month and get to know ChatGPT-4. Comment content: I have one thread set up as the AI being a data science teacher at a university. Another thread is set up purely for me asking whether the AI can make code that I give it better. I have gotten completely different answers for the same code in those two threads. In one example, the teacher thread said the code was perfectly good, and no improvements were needed but when I put that same code in to the make it better thread, it totally optimized the code by using more advanced solutions. So I think it was smart enough to recognize that from a teacher perspective I was accomplishing the goal, but the other thread was working entirely differently. To the point of prompt engineering.
Replies:
['I am perplexed by how good a language model has become', 'This should be no surprise, it comes down to "frequency". IF and only IF the optimal solution was the most frequently seen by the model while training will it become the answer. IF NOT you get whatever had the highest representation. By specifically asking it for "optimized" you narrowed the scope, thus the answer changes to "the most frequent of the 'optimized' answers".
As for prompt engineering, yes, and that's why ChatGPT isn't the "universal" game changer people make it to be. To be useful it needs someone that knows WHAT to ask and HOW to interpret the answer.
It's still the age old issue of client/business <-> developer communication. One or both can't express itself/themselves clearly (or truthfully) and the other or both can't interpret the answer.
If anything, things like ChatGPT will turbo-boost people that have a decent understanding of communication while obsolescing the rest.', '@erazerPT Excellent, succinct analysis.  Your point about business <-> subject matter expert communication comes to the forefront with every new wave of disruptive technology.   At those times, discipline scanners are worth their weight in gold.  (I’d say worth their weight in crypto, but…)', '@@sarangtamirisa5090 The human world is run on language. Now so far Chat GPT 3/4 is just using one form of language, verbal but it all ready understand images, how long before it does live video and understand body language.', '@@DavidKnowles0 Yeah, the potential seems endless.']
